WOMAN WITH THE BALLOT Dr. H. C. Morrison of Louisville, Ky., sets forth the political expediency of woman suffrage:— Nine states in our great Union have conferred upon woman the right of fran- chise. California, Utah. Wyoming, Colo- rado, Kansas. Idaho. Oregon, Washing- ton and Arizona, have given tto[sic.] woman the privilege of the ballot. The indica- tions are that other states will soon fall into line, and it is reasonable to suppose in the not distant future the woman- hood of the United States will have equal rights with men at the polls. The drift is so strong in the direction of suffrage that politicians will be very rare who will undertake to turn the onmoving tide backward. The increase of representation in the states granting suffrage, will powerfully influence other states to increase their representation by increasing their number of voters. However conservative any part of the country may be on the subject, no section will be willing or could hardly afford to entirely outclassed in representation from other parts of nation because its women were deprived of the ballot. Men will reason that if the entire west gives the ballot to its women, the east must do so in order to compete with the west on the floor of congress; the same will hold good with reference to north and south. The indications are now that the tide of sympathy with suffrage will continue to advance with the idea and it becomes a practical fact.
In the great battle against the liquor traffic we have been profoundly grieved and outraged when we have seen illiterate negroes flock to the polls and vote for the saloon., while intelligent and consecrated women whose offspring were to become the victims of the whiskey traffic, had to remain in subdued silence. Any fair mind must admit that it hardly looks the proper thing for an illiterate carriage driver who pays practically no taxes, and is scarcely able to give reason for his actions, And is often only the tool in the hands of designing politicians, to cast a vote to increase taxation, or heap other burdens and inconveniences on property owners, when the intelligent, cultured woman whose carriage he drives, who pays large taxes, must remain silent and inactive. It sounds, quite reasonable when we are told that taxation without representation is not in harmony with the American idea or with the high standards of equity.
There are many reason why the citizens of this republic should revere the name of Abraham Lincoln--not the least among them being the fact that he was the first prominent public man in America to advocate women's suffrage, in that memorable declaration which has not become a classic.
